title: Georgia House - Day 35 (2026-06-20)
summary:
Here is a summary of the key points from the Georgia House session transcript:

**Overview:**
The session featured the introduction of several bills, including HB316, HB516, HR 1551, and SR 1010. There were also notable speeches, procedural moments, and recorded votes.

**Key Actions:**
- **HB316:** No description provided
- **HB516:** No description provided 
- **HR 1551:** No description provided
- **SR 1010:** No description provided

**Bills Introduced (First Reading):**
- HB316
- HB516 
- HR 1551
- SR 1010

**Notable Moments:**
- Opening prayer and scripture reading by Reverend Dr. Simon Mainwaring, focused on the importance of empathy and serving the needs of all people.
- Procedural details around roll call and members reporting to the chamber.

**Votes:**
- Several votes were mentioned, including some that were "opposed" and some that "passed". However, the specific bills associated with these votes were not provided.

**Attendance:**
- A full roll call was taken to establish quorum.

**Adjournment:**
The transcript did not specify when the session adjourned or the date of the next scheduled session.

All members present will please say aye or yes when the clerk calls your name to signify your presence in the body. The clerk will unlock the machines and call the roll. We'll begin our day with Scripture reading and prayer by the Chaplain, after which we will pledge allegiance to the flag of our country. Our Chaplain this morning will be introduced by the gentleman from the 80th House District Representative Matthew Wilson, Representative Wilson. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Colleagues, it is my distinct pleasure this morning to introduce you to the Reverend Dr. Simon Main Warning. Simon is a director of all saints at Piscobal Church here in Atlanta. All saints is my church home and it's also home to several members of the General Assembly, of course the distinguished Mayor Margaret Oliver, Senator Elena Parent, former Representative Ed Lindsey, and a few others who have served in this body. As you're about to hear Simon is originally from England and he was educated at Oxford, Cambridge, Harvard, and Birmingham where he earned a PhD in biblical theology. Mr. Speaker, I'm told that's not the Birmingham next door but the one across the pond. Simon has ministered for the past 23 years in schools, hospitals, and parish churches. He's also a scholar, has authored two books and a number of journal articles. As director, at all saints, Simon has the privilege of leading our staff and lay leaders and engage the parish in the life of the city of Atlanta. He's done that for the last three years as the leader of our church and one of the most important things that he has done is re-engaged the leadership that already existed within the congregation of all saints into the social justice movement of the city of Atlanta. Simon serves on the board of the Absalom Jones Center for Racial Healing here in Atlanta and collaborates with church leaders throughout Midtown and downtown to offer the voice of the needs of our neighbors and further the mission of the church. Although he told me he is an avid Atlanta United fan, he enjoys cheering his beloved soccer team Tottenham Hotspur, which will get you nowhere in the ways it means committee by the way. He does enjoy time with his family, he's Mary Tamanika, who is also an Episcopal priest and rector of St. Martin in the fields Episcopal Church located in my district in Burkhaven and they have three children. Please welcome the Reverend Dr. Simon Mainwaring. Mr. Speaker, distinguished representatives, it is a privilege to be with you here today to begin your work with a moment of reflection and prayer. Thank you, Representative Wilson for your generous welcome and thank you to each of you who have responded to the call to serve the common good in this place. My devotion for you this morning begins with a friend of mine and a pressurer of my church named Carl. Some time ago Carl and I had dinner along with a small number of other church members. We were a mix of ages, of races, of genders, of views of the world and memories of life. We're invited to share stories of significance from our lives. Carl told the story of his career in the Social Security Administration and how he had been sent by the Administration to law school in Baltimore. During class he got to know a young woman. She was white, he was black. She broached the topic of having lunch together several times hoping that Carl might actually invite her but Carl felt sorely aware that there were only two places to eat in the hall of town where a black man could take a white woman to lunch. The railway station and Woolworth's department store he felt embarrassed by his lack of options and made excuses two or three times until finally he swallowed his pride and that long awaited lunch paved the way for a lifelong friendship. Later that night as we sat together talking the sheer everyday quality of Carl's story struck me. Young love looking for a place to eat and every day reality of segregation. The everyday matters because it is there that we will either hold on to hope or lose it. Jesus of Nazareth was profoundly interested in the everyday. His vision of human community, what the Bible calls the Kingdom of God, is not one of abstract principles or high falluten language. Jesus' vision is of bread on the table of children dying to young of prisoners languishing without justice or families who mourn loved ones of the life of the poor in a world too much in love with riches. As a follower of Jesus I'll take the liberty of pointing out that Jesus concerns seem very much like your own in this place. Here is where people's needs, the life of children and the longings for justice of the people of this state have their reckoning. Jesus taught that the measure of a people is how truly it honors and remembers the least, the poor, the oppressed and the forgotten. That is how you will be measured also. And so I pray for you this day. I pray that you may be granted the gift of a deep and abiding empathy for the people of this state, especially those who are different to you and those who see the world differently to you. I pray that you might be struck by the everyday nature of people's challenges and that you might discover ever richer ways to see the world as they see it so that you will know how it is you are called to build the kind of society Jesus proclaimed where every child of God, no matter their color or creed, is valued by each of us on the earth as deeply as God values them in the heavens. And so in the name of that God, I offer this blessing. Would you please stand. Oh God, creator and sustainer of all life, stir the hearts of your people, strengthen their wills, enliven their minds and inspire their spirits to see your grace alive in the lives of all people. Amen the Lord your God bless you and keep you now and evermore. Amen. Would you join me in the pledge. I pray that you are the nation under God, the indivisible, the liberty and justice for all. It's very, very good. Thank you so. Good job Matthew. Thank you. Doorkeepers will unlock the doors. in the house I bring you Senate Bill 395. So often we hear about hospital closings and this is a bill that comes out of a hospital success. Down in Savannah we had a hospital that was failing, had been in the red for several years, it was purchased, and in a third, three year period it is now in the black, it is paid all its bond and debtiness and its indebtedness off, and it has a near revocable trust nearing $100 million for indigent care. The bill changes, there is a stipulation in the law that says that can only go up to people that are 125% of poverty level, this would change it to 138. It would also allow for them not to just do it for hospital care, but for clinic care and preventing type care. It also has new rules about how the money can be invested. The funds are not to be used for anything except indigent care and that it provides for a better way to invest like we do with our teacher retirement, conservative, so that it can make more money to be used for indigent care. If there are no questions, Mr. Speaker, I will yell well and ask for a favorable vote. This would apply to any hospital that had this kind of trust and had met these requirements across our state. Representative, that kind of a decision is a little bit above my pay grade. I will say that it's my understanding that once you reach 101% of the poverty level, that you are eligible for programs under the Bama Care better known as the Affordable Care Act, and that those insurance type programs can be purchased and with money given to the person of where they are practically free. That bill was going to sunset this year. So this section 1 merely extends the sunset for three years. Section 2 authorizes Commissioner to change to the deductive earnings. But only if two things are triggered and they both got to happen if we are in a state of emergency and the legislature is not in session, this will give the Department the Commissioner certain powers. Section 4 changes the maximum benefit weeks on a sliding scale, depending on what the unemployment rate is. And then Section 5 allows the Commissioner to establish a work sharing program that is provided in the Federal Unemployment Act and that is the bill. We'll stand for any questions if there are any. Senate Bill 443 by Senator Stone, the 23rd Annters and the 24th and most the 53rd Annters will be titled back to men chapter 4, title 18, the official to Georgia annotated relating the Garnersman proceedings so as their vice procedures for Garnersman proceedings this bill have referred to committee on judiciary. Now committee recommends that this bill do pass. Chair recognizes Chairman Welch to present the bill. There we go. Thank you. Thank you, Mr. Leader. I present to you Senate Bill 443. This is a Garnishment Update Bill. Last term we had passed a comprehensive rewrite of the Garnishment laws in state of Georgia and oftentimes we have to go back and clean that up. And so what we've done in this bill, and you'll notice that most of the text in the back is all forms that are being updated in our code section. I do want to point out some substantive changes that need to be you need to be aware of in the podium on this bill. Number one is that we are we are now authorizing the voluntary modification of the amounts of the Garnishment if the defendant and the plaintiff agree. This is at lines 98 through 100. This is an adjustment that actually makes it easier for Garnish for the Garnishee if you're the employer of the person's whose wages are being garnished. That you can actually work out an arrangement that works out better for the person the Garnish, the defendant. So as the Garnishee you can work with the defendant as always the plaintiff agrees as well. So this is an improvement I think especially given our certain current times this is an improvement in the legislation. Number two is on lines 50 on page two. We are continuing Garnishments instead of having to file a refile Garnishments every six months we're moving to three years. Why? The simple answer is it saves everybody money. Cost of refiling for the Garnishment are typically passed on to the defendant, passed on to the plaintiff initially, then to the defendant. And so this would actually eliminate those costs and actually make it better for the defendant, the person's whose wages are being garnered. Student loans, private student loans were not covered before. Public student loans you can only garner to 15%. This legislation at lines 68 through 70 actually now allow for that to be written down. Private student loans for 25% to 15%. So that puts them in line with public student loans which is better. And then also there are procedural changes that are made into the bill that actually make notifications and distributions of the money's easier and confirmation of those distributions better as well. Those are the main substantive changes in the legislation the rest of them are cleanup measures in the legislation. I'll be happy to take any questions if you have them. I'll be pleased to ask you a question. Is Senator Stone's legislation and I would ask for your favorable consideration of this. I see one question. Do you do you yield? Yes, I do. Mr. Speaker. I recognize as representative Bentley to your left for a question. Yes. Mr. Speaker. Mr. gentlemen, yield. I do. Yes, ma'am. Representative, can you explain to me exactly when we mentioned public schools. I thought of Fort Valley State University. Can you explain to me exactly how this legislation will affect someone that just recently graduated from Fort Valley State University with student loans and don't have the means to pay back those loans at this time. Another question. Does not alter the current law that deals with student loans. So if a student that graduate from Fort Valley State finds himself in a job that has a problem and is unable to pay back their student loans, then those loans could be garnished under current law. But only 15% of their wages could be garnished as opposed to 25% which is the typical standard amount. But this bill actually would change that for private student loans, it's now 15% under this legislation. And furthermore, it actually gives the flexibility so that the garnishee, the defendant who owes the money and the creditor can all actually adjust the amounts that are paid in order to account for payments of changes in lifestyle, someone's lost a job and the family income. You may have a child that needs extra care medical attention. We all know these things happen and there needs to be some flexibility in this law would allow that. Very good. Thank you for your work on this bill. Thank you, ma'am. Do you yield for a further question? I do, yes. Chair recognizes representative Jasmine Clark, the gallery to your right. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Does it gentlemen, you? I do, yes ma'am. So can you clarify for me online 50? It says that a continuing garnish shall include the next one thousand ninety five days of three years. Does that mean that a person who is being garnished will absolutely be under garnishment for three years? No, it's only until it's paid but it is a continuing garnishment whereby the debt is owed and it lingers longer than three years. Then what would happen now, under current law, every six months you'd have to file another continuing garnishment and those expenses for filing get passed on typically from the plaintiff and then rolled into what the defendant would pay. So moving it to three years, if it's that long, it may be longer, maybe six years, it may be nine years, but that would allow it to extend out. So we just pertain to continuing garnishments and for the amounts that have not been fully repaid. Thank you. Yes ma'am. Thank you. With that, Mr. Speaker, I will yield the well and I ask for your favorable consideration of Senate bill 443. Thank you. Chair recognizes Chairman Eftration for a morning order. Chair recognizes Representative Vernon Jones for a morning order. Chair recognizes Representative Turner for a morning order. A total of 10 minutes for all the morning orders. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. American history is not a history of perfection, but rather the betterment of people who call our country home. And betterment means change for the positive, which is why I've joined with our colleagues here in a bipartisan effort to draft HR 1551. Now is the time for change in the United States capital and for Georgia to honor a man who worked for the betterment of all humankind. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. peacefully, but forcefully, called for an end to the hate and prejudice and deserves his place as an honor. As a representative of Georgia in the United States capital, Statuary Hall, collection by replacing Alexander Hamilton Stevens. Both men were powerful orders. Both men commanded the attention of their audience, but their messages could not be more contrasting from one another. Whereas Dr. King spoke of equality, liberty, freedom and justice for all people. Stevens literally sought to justify slavery as a natural institution due to the inferiority of blacks. Not only is this wrong, it's evil, and it's a belief that stands in direct violation of our moral compass as Americans. Statuary Hall is intended to serve as a remembrance of honor great Americans that individually represent our 50 state. The Hall honors men and women like Helen Keller of Alabama, Sakakowia from North Dakota religious leaders like Father Damien from Hawaii and Mother Joseph, the Sacred Heart from Washington. But sadly, only two black patriots are featured as full statues in the United States capital, Rosa Parks and Frederick Douglass. Neither are part of the Statuary Hall collection, which is intended to represent the diversity of our states. I see no person more fitting to represent that better minute of the collection than Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. of Georgia. This does not mean that we destroy history. I believe it's important that we return the Statue of Mr. Stevens to Georgia so his legacy can be studied and remembered in context, including remembering the darker chapters of our shared history. However, we should reserve that place of honor for one who has truly committed their life, has committed their life for the betterment of all of us. I know this piece of legislation was dropped after Cross Over Day, and traditionally this would mean it wouldn't pass this year, but 2020 is not a normal year. This issue has been overlooked for too long. So if there's any way we can do this this year, I think it's a time. It's only one step, one of many steps that we need to be taking to show unity and our march towards healing in this time. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Chair recognizes Representative McCloud for a morning order. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. Big up to my colleagues. I'm here today to sound the alarm for this disastrous administered primary election we just witnessed. The bright spot belongs to the people that showed up and voted, especially the millennials. Our country is a republic, and to achieve represented democracy, the vote has to be the nucleus. We either believe in our constitution or we don't. The first three words we the people are the only ones that can make this republic success. Voter participation that is not 100% is a failure. Encouraging people to vote is patriotic. A few weeks before the primary election, I start again calls from constituents that they had not received their absentee ballot. As the days got closer, I had to instruct them to go ahead and vote in person in a pandemic that put their lives at risk. When I contacted the county's election supervisor, she said things were going well. The day before our primary election, the Georgia legislated black caucus, met with the Secretary of State, and we expressed our concerns about the election. The response was everything was going well. On June 9th, election day, I got a call at 7 a.m. from a voter saying that she had her polling location and there was no machines. At first, I thought she was at an early voting site, but she said no. I'm at the church, I'm supposed to vote at. She went early because she had day surgery. She never got the opportunity to vote. I called my county's election supervisor and found out that 28 locations opened without machines. On June 17th, I was told the ballots were fully count, and about 20 minutes later, I got a call from a candidate saying that several ballots were missing, and then several candidates said that their votes went missing. In 2019, elected Democrats objected to the passage of HB316 because we were concerned about the electronic machines. The experts recommended hand written paper ballots. I'm calling on the Secretary of State to fix these problems in November. The country and the world is watching Georgia. Knowledge is the most powerful gift we give to ourselves, but the vote is the most powerful thing we give to each other. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I yield well. Chair recognizes representative Lopez Romero for a morning order. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I wanted to make sure that we recognize the Supreme Court decision that will maintain DACA as it stands currently, and to understand that its rationale was based on this administration not being able to provide the most basic rationale that was not capricious or arbitrary. But beyond that, I want to highlight why it matters to each of us sitting here, because this is not just a national decision taken by our Supreme Court, but rather I want to highlight one of my first legislative aids that I had. Marisol was raised in Savannah, attended Armstrong University, because she had to pay out of state tuition despite growing up in Savannah and graduating from her local public school, she still was not able to pay in state tuition. So she worked multiple jobs, including babysitting, translating, and on campus, in addition to that, she spent her legislative, my first legislative session here with me. She is an exceptionally hard working, phenomenally smart young lady that I have the very happy to say that she is now going to start law school at Syracuse University this fall. These are the young individuals that are culturally American by every standard, and culturally American expression of their love by being able to provide their talent, their skills. And so I want to highlight and honor individuals like her that are working every single day to make our state better, to provide a face of greater opportunity for our state and reminding us what work we should be doing. That being said in this body as we move forward, I will continue to ask you for us to provide in state equity for in state tuition for DACA and undocumented students. And as I had previously reminded you, this is also personal as it affects us, because I myself was undocumented for 12 years of my life, had not been for the legislation that President Ronald Reagan signed. I would not have been able to eventually apply for my green card and then to become a U.S. citizen and sit here in this chamber with you as colleagues. So thank you so much, and we have lots of work to do, definitely at the federal level for a comprehensive immigration reform, but a lot of work that needs to be done in this chamber to ensure that we are a welcoming state. Thank you. Thank you, Mr. Speaker, who you are well. I would like to recognize this representative Vernon Jones for the final one minute of morning orders. Thank you, Mr. Speaker. I'll keep it to 59 seconds, hopefully. Members of this distinguished body, I do want to say that Representative Scott Turner has brought about a piece of legislation as well overdue, and that is supporting one of the two statues to be replaced with the Statue of Dott the King and the United States halls, Capitol Halls. So I would like to thank all the law enforcement agencies and officers at this particular Capitol who looked out for us each and every day. That is important. We appreciate you and we value you. And finally, I just want to say that in the midst of all this hate that's been passed around, the only force that can conquer hate is love. So I ask each and every one of you to keep that in mind and love our neighbors, I say thank you, Mr. Speaker. That completes morning orders.
